Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Shared Decision-Making in Major Surgery for Older Adults

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive a question prompt list brochure or standard care.

Participants.evidence: involved 43 surgeons and 446 patients aged 60 or older with at least one comorbidity at outpatient surgical clinics across five academic centers.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive a question prompt list brochure or standard care.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the use of shared decision-making in surgical consultations.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the OPTION5 score, measuring shared decision-making (range 0-100), assessed over consultations from June 1, 2016, to November 31, 2018.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment ensured.

Number_Randomised.evidence: involved 43 surgeons and 446 patients aged 60 or older with at least one comorbidity at outpatient surgical clinics across five academic centers.

Result_Outcome.evidence: the mean OPTION5 score was 34.7 (SD 20.6), with no significant difference between the intervention (mean 36.7, SD 21.2) and control (mean 32.9, SD 19.9) groups (effect estimate 3.80; 95% CI, −0.30 to 8.00; P = .07).
